article.title: Towards a population synthesis model of self-gravitating disc fragmentation and tidal downsizing II: The effect of fragment-fragment interactions

choices: The initial surface density profile and viscous transport parameter Î± of a protostellar disc, with the initial locations of fragments marked.
The evolution of surface density and temperature over time in a self-gravitating protostellar disc.
The relationship between fragment mass and semimajor axis in a population synthesis model of disc fragmentation.
The growth of dust grains in a protostellar disc, with and without the influence of spiral density waves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between the left and right panels of Figure 2?
choices: The left panel shows a system with fewer initial fragments than the right panel.
The left panel shows the results of a simulation with N-Body physics turned off, while the right panel shows a simulation with N-Body physics active.
The left panel shows the mass distribution of brown dwarfs, while the right panel shows the mass distribution of giant planets.
The left panel shows the results of a simulation with rapid migration, while the right panel shows a simulation with slow migration.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 illustrate about the mass distribution of objects in the simulation?
choices: The initial mass distribution of fragments is heavily skewed towards low-mass objects.
The majority of ejected objects are low-mass fragments, while bound objects are predominantly high-mass.
Fragmentation predominantly produces objects with masses between 1 and 10 Jupiter masses.
Fragment-fragment interactions have a negligible effect on the final mass distribution of objects.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does Figure 4 demonstrate regarding the multiplicity of planetary systems?
choices: N-Body interactions significantly increase the number of systems with high multiplicity (3 or more planets).
Systems with a single planet become the most common outcome when N-Body interactions are considered.
The inclusion of N-Body interactions has a negligible effect on the multiplicity of planetary systems.
The number of systems with no surviving planets decreases when N-Body interactions are considered.
